metadata.title: Development of heterogeneous palladium catalyst for perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of alkenes with alkyl halides

Research Paper Development of heterogeneous palladium catalyst for perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of alkenes with alkyl halides Shuyu Yang a Bo Zhang a Heng Yang a Yu Feng a Guodong Zhang a Pan Gao a Xuehua Zhang b ⁎ Feng Chen a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Siwangting Road 180 225002, Yangzhou PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Yangzhou University Siwangting Road 180 Yangzhou 225002 PR China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Siwangting Road 180 225002, Yangzhou PR China b School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Yancheng Teachers University, No. 2 Hope Avenue South Road, 224007, Yancheng, PR China School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering Yancheng Teachers University No. 2 Hope Avenue South Road Yancheng 224007 PR China bYancheng Teachers University 224007, Yancheng, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Olefin's difunctionalization to complex compounds is scientifically significant due to its diverse synthesis potential. In this study, we developed a ligand-free palladium on CeO2 catalyst that facilitates the olefin perfluoroalkyl carbonylation with carbon monoxide, providing a sustainable route to β-perfluoroalkyl esters with wide functional group tolerance. This catalyst exhibited high activity and good recyclability. It not only reduces noble metal consumption but also eliminates the need for environmentally toxic precious homogeneous phosphorus ligands. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbonylation Alkenes Heterogeneous palladium catalyst 1 Introduction Esters are widely found in natural and pharmaceutical products, serving as essential building blocks in organic synthesis[1]. Direct carbonylation of olefins to esters[2–6] has become an effective method compared to traditional esterification of carboxylic acids with alcohols[7], enabling the synthesis of multifunctionalized esters through multi-component reactions. Meanwhile, the increasing interest in fluorinated compounds, known for their exceptional chattels in pharmaceuticals and material chemistry[8–10], underscores the need for new strategies to construct fluorine-containing esters. While the unsaturated bonds carbonylation to esters using transition metal catalysts is well-established, it often relies on costly phosphorus or nitrogen ligands. A promising strategy is the difunctionalization which can introduce fluoro and carbonyl groups simultaneously. For instance, the olefins perfluoroalkylative carbonylation to produce β-perfluoroalkyl esters has been achieved with homogeneous catalysts like Pd(OAc)₂/BINAP[11]. However, despite their high activity and selectivity, these systems face challenges such as high metal loading, and the expense of precious ligands, limiting their industrial applicability. Additionally, recovering and reusing homogeneous catalysts remains a significant hurdle. In this context, heterogeneous catalysts are favored in the industry for their unique advantages, including easy separation from the reaction system, reusability, minimal metal residues, and the absence of ligands[12,13]. Therefore, the development of heterogeneous catalysts to realize alkene perfluoroalkylative carbonylation is of great practical importance[14–19]. In our previous work, we developed a titanium oxide-supported palladium catalyst for the alkene perfluoroalkylative carbonylation using perfluoroiodine alkanes and phenols[18]. However, when the nucleophiles were changed to aliphatic alcohols, the performance was suboptimal, and the Pd loading of the Pd@TiO₂−400-H₂ catalyst was still too high at 5.1 wt%. Given the cost and substrate scope limitations, we continued to explore new catalysts that could reduce palladium loading and broaden substrate applicability. In this study, we present a heterogeneous Pd@CeO₂ catalyst for synthesizing β-perfluoroalkyl esters from inactivated alkenes (Scheme 1 B). Unlike homogeneous catalytic systems, this heterogeneous catalyst eliminates the need for expensive and toxic ligands. Moreover, the palladium loading is reduced to 0.65 mol%, maintaining high activity over four cycles without significant performance decline and demonstrating a broad substrate scope. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Optimization of reaction conditions Cerium oxide is often used as a catalyst or catalyst carrier in catalysis science[20–23]. First, we prepared different CeO2-supported palladium catalysts and tested the activity using 4-phenyl-1-butene (1a), perfluorobutyl iodide (2a), and 1-iodohexane (3a) with Cs₂CO₃ under 40 bar of carbon monoxide in 1,4-dioxane. The CeO₂ supported palladium catalyst calcined at 400 °C in 5 % H2/Ar (Pd@CeO2–400-H2) produced product 4aaa with an 83 % yield (Table 1 , entry 1). The catalyst prepared with PPh3 demonstrated similar activity for this reaction (Table 1, entry 2). Adjusting the temperature of the calcination process revealed that 400 °C was optimum (Table 1, entries 3–4). The catalysts calcined in nitrogen or air atmospheres showed lower activity, yielding product in 74–75 % (Table 1, entries 5–6). Next, we screened the reaction conditions using Pd@CeO2–400-H2 catalyst. Firstly, various bases were tested and cesium carbonate can provide the best yield (see details in Supporting Information). Subsequently, several solvents, including DCE, 2-Me-THF, benzotrifluoride, acetonitrile, and methanol were tested with this heterogeneous Pd catalyst. The product 4aaa attained in 83 % yield using 1,4-dioxane as solvent (Table 2 , entries 1–4). When CH₃CN and CH₃OH were used as solvents, trace amounts of products were detected (Table 2, entries 5–6). The catalyst amount was also tested and a yield of 73 % was observed when 20 mg catalyst was used (Table 2, entry 7). Increasing the catalyst amount gave a similar yield as 80 % (Table 2, entry 8). The reaction temperature also affected the reaction and 80 °C was the best condition (Table 2, entries 9–10). Additionally, increasing the equivalent of base resulted in a slight yield increase (Table 2, entries 11–12). Reducing the CO pressure to 30 bar resulted in a lower yield (Table 2, entries 13). Finally, when 1-iodohexane was replaced by 1-bromohexane, the reaction could also proceed well and 62 % yield of 4aaa was obtained. 2.2 Substrate scope With the optimal reaction conditions established, we explored the substrate scope of this alkene perfluoroalkylative carbonylation (Scheme 2 ). A variety of alkyl halides, including alkyl bromides, alkyl iodides, and alkyl chlorides, were successfully transformed into the corresponding β-perfluoroalkyl substituted alkyl esters (4aaa–4aan). Both straight-chain and branched alkyl halides performed well in the reaction (4aaa–4aaf). Moreover, remotely functionalized groups with varying electronic properties—such as cyclopropyl, halogen atoms, phenoxy, and trifluoromethyl—were all compatible with the reaction (4aag–4aan). In contrast, alkyl chlorides significantly hindered the reaction, primarily due to the higher bond dissociation energies of the C(sp³)-Cl bonds compared to the C(sp³)-Br and C(sp³)-I bonds. However, when 1,2-dichloroethane was employed as both solvent and reagent, the corresponding product 4aai was obtained with a yield of 31 %. Next, various alkyl olefins were examined under optimal conditions. The terminal alkenes can proceed this transformation to products 4baa-4faa in 49–92 % yields. The internal alkene substrate was also compatible but gave a lower yield, such as cyclohexene which can convert into 4 gaa in 16 % yield. When functional groups like the carbonyl group exist in the alkene, the reaction performed not well with only 12 % yield (4haa). The styrene was also tested under standard conditions. No desired product was isolated. Finally, several commercially available perfluoroalkyl iodides were tested, yielding the desired products 4aca–4aga in 70–91 % yields. Notably, when CF3I was employed as the substrate, the desired product 3aba was isolated in 16 % yield. Notably, this process can also be successfully applied to late-stage simultaneous perfluoroalkylation and carbonylation modifications of biologically active molecules. Alkenes modified with cholesterol or vitamin derivatives were transformed into the corresponding products in moderate yields (4iaa–4jaa). 2.3 Characterization of the optimal catalyst Thorough characterizations were completed to study the enhanced activity of this Pd@CeO₂−400-H₂ catalyst. The palladium loading for Pd@CeO₂−400-H₂ was measured at 0.42 wt% by ICP-OES. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern confirmed the CeO₂ structure for these materials prepared under different conditions (JCPDS card no 75–0120). However, the typical diffraction peak of palladium was not found. This result could be attributed to the effective dispersion of palladium on CeO₂ while the size of palladium sites is small (Scheme 3 ). HRTEM pictures were collected and palladium particles were not found for catalyst Pd@CeO2–400-H. This result confirmed that palladium should be dispersed on support evenly (Scheme 4 a, b). To gain deeper insight into the surface chemical composition of the best catalyst Pd@CeO₂−400-H₂, we have performed the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. The spectrum of Ce 3d gave six peaks at 882.1, 888.8, 898.1, 900.7, 907.2, and 916.5 eV These peaks correspond to the characteristic Ce4+ species (Scheme 5 c) [24]. In Scheme 5d, two peaks at 335.1 eV and 340.2 eV should be Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2. Meanwhile, the peaks at 337.0 eV and 342.5 eV can be assigned to PdOx species. The calculation of the percentage of Pd0 is 54 %. 3 Catalyst recycling The recyclability is a major advantage of heterogeneous catalysts. We conducted the catalyst recycling experiments for Pd@CeO₂−400-H₂ catalyst under standard reaction conditions. The catalyst exhibited stable performance during first four cycles (see details in Supporting Information). When the Pd loading was increased to 2.5 wt%, the catalyst maintained high activity even after six cycles (Scheme 6 a). XPS analysis for the catalyst after revealed that the CeO2 did not change after few cycles. However, the Pd 3d spectra did not have a significant peak profile duo to the low content of palladium. Finally, HRTEM characterization showed that the morphology of used catalyst remained unchanged (Scheme 6b). 4 Mechanism study To investigate the mechanism of this heterogeneous carbonylation reaction, control experiments were performed (Scheme 7 ). Firstly, free radical inhibitor 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidoxyl (TEMPO) influenced this reaction evidently and no desired product 4aaa was formed when 2 equivalents TEMPO was added using but‑3-en-1-ylbenzene as substrate. TEMPO can react with perfluoralkyl radical species and this intermediate was detected in HR-MS. These results indicate that a free radical process should be involved during the reaction. Perfluorobutyl iodide could generate perfluorobutyl radical which can react with the double bond of substrate 1a to form a new radical species. It may capture the iodine free radicals to generate intermediate 4aa. We performed the reaction using 4aa with 3a under standard conditions and 95 % yield of 4aaa was isolated. However, when 2 equivalents TEMPO were added, no product was detected. Therefore, 4aa could be an intermediate that proceeds the reaction through a radical pathway. Finally, we have conducted the reaction of 1a with 2a with or without catalyst. The addition product 5aa was not detected due to the alkaline condition and the elimination product 6aa was isolated in 95 % and 64 % yields and the ratio of E/Z isomer was 3.8:1 (see supporting information). According to the above control experiments and reported works, we propose the reaction mechanisms in Scheme 8 . The dehalogenation of perfluoroalkyl halides will form perfluoroalkyl radical. It can react with the double bond of olefin to generate carbon radical species A which could interact with the palladium center of Pd@CeO2–400-H2 catalyst to generate intermediate B. Then CO insertion will give acyl palladium species D. Meanwhile, in the presence of cesium carbonate, alkyl halide hydrocarbons convert into alkoxy cesium E which will attack species D. Lastly, the perfluoroalkylative carbonylation product is obtained by reductive elimination and palladium sites are regenerated. Moreover, the pathway from the addition product of olefin with perfluoroalkyl halides (C) cannot be excluded under the reaction conditions although the addition product C is not formed under the alkali conditions (see supporting information). It is worth noting that although perfluoroalkyl iodoalkanes and alkyl haloalkanes are present in the reaction system at the same time, perfluoroalkyl iodoalkanes can generate radical species easily through a SET mechanism because the perfluoroalkyl iodides are relatively good electron acceptors than alkyl iodides. [25–26] Besides, the bond-dissociation energies of CCl and C-Br are higher than C-I bond. Therefore, the C-Br and CCl bond cleavage is difficult than C-I bond. 5 Conclusions In summary, our research has focused on developing a range of CeO2-supported Pd catalysts and applied to perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of alkenes with alkyl halides. The Pd@CeO2–400-H2 catalyst has demonstrated high activity and selectivity for this four-component synthesis of β-perfluoroalkyl esters with good recyclability, and broad functional group tolerance. These characteristics make this heterogeneous palladium catalyst highly suitable for further industrial applications. Ongoing research in our laboratory is exploring additional applications of CeO2-supported heterogeneous palladium catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Olefin's difunctionalization to complex compounds is scientifically significant due to its diverse synthesis potential. In this study, we developed a ligand-free palladium on CeO2 catalyst that facilitates the olefin perfluoroalkyl carbonylation with carbon monoxide, providing a sustainable route to β-perfluoroalkyl esters with wide functional group tolerance. This catalyst exhibited high activity and good recyclability. It not only reduces noble metal consumption but also eliminates the need for environmentally toxic precious homogeneous phosphorus ligands.

coredata.dc:title: Development of heterogeneous palladium catalyst for perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of alkenes with alkyl halides
